content: Describe how a web page is structured.

A web page is structured using HTML (Hypertext Markup Language), which provides the basic framework for how content is displayed in a web browser. Here’s a breakdown of the key components of a web page structure: 1. **DOCTYPE Declaration**: This is the first thing in an HTML document, and it tells the browser what version of HTML the page is written in. For HTML5, it is ``. 2. **HTML Element**: This is the root element that wraps all other elements on the page. It is written as `` and contains the `` and `` elements. 3. **Head Element**: The `` section contains meta-information about the document, such as the title, links to stylesheets, character set declarations, and other metadata. Key components include: - ``: Sets the title of the web page, as seen in the browser tab. - `<meta>` tags: Provide metadata such as character set, author, and description. - `<link>` tags: Link to external resources like CSS stylesheets. - `<script>` tags: Can include or link to JavaScript files that need to be loaded before the main content. 4. **Body Element**: The `<body>` section contains all the content that is displayed on the web page, such as text, images, links, and other media. Key elements within the body include: - Text content elements like `<h1>`, `<p>`, `<span>`, and `<div>`. - Media elements like `<img>`, `<video>`, and `<audio>`. - Links and navigation elements like `<a>`, `<nav>`, and `<ul>`. - Form elements like `<form>`, `<input>`, `<textarea>`, and `<button>`. - Semantic elements like `<header>`, `<footer>`, `<article>`, and `<section>` which help define the structure of the content. 5. **CSS (Cascading Style Sheets)**: While not part of HTML, CSS is used to style the HTML elements and control the layout. CSS can be included in the `<head>` using `<style>` tags or linked externally using `<link>`. 6. **JavaScript**: JavaScript is used to add interactivity and dynamic behavior to web pages. It can be embedded in the HTML using `<script>` tags or linked externally. 7. **Comments**: HTML comments (`<!-- Comment -->`) can be used to leave notes or explanations within the code, which are not displayed in the browser. This basic structure forms the backbone of a web page, allowing developers to create complex and interactive websites by leveraging additional technologies like CSS for styling and JavaScript for scripting.
